Award.AwardTitle: Ecoclimate Teleconnections: Effects of a Shifting Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are to quantify the impact of ecosystem-climate, or ecoclimate, teleconnections on regions remote to the original forcing and to identify feedbacks associated with the change in ecosystem structure, function, and productivity in those locations. Prior work has shown that an increase in mid latitude forest cover can raise northern hemisphere temperature and has the ability to shift the general circulation of the tropics and the location of precipitation associated with the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). This ecosystem-driven teleconnection links productivity in land regions remote to one another through the circulation of the atmosphere.

Through an offline-coupling approach with both a global-scale circulation model and a model of ecosystem dynamics, the first order impact of feedbacks associated with changes in vegetation cover will be quantified. In particular the impact of mid latitude tree cover on the location of the ITCZ will be quantified and the resulting change in tropical forest productivity and structure will be assessed. The impact of any changes in tropical forest structure back onto the global climate system will also be examined.

The scientific questions that will be addressed in this project are the following: Can large-scale changes in mid latitude tree cover destabilize ecosystems in other parts of the world through atmospheric teleconnections? How are these ecoclimate teleconnections communicated through the atmosphere? How much change in mid latitude tree cover is needed to impact forests in the tropics? Improved understanding of ecosystem-climate interactions has substantial broader impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to better understand the relationship between where trees grow and atmospheric circulation. This project focused on using simulation techniques to find out how climate responds to plant cover and how plants function. As part of this project we trained graduate students to become the next generation of scientists who can research and communicate across disciplinary boundaries of climate science and ecosystem science and together we worked with middle school girls to engage them in science.

 

In previous research, the PI identified how the addition of large areas of trees in North America and Europe creates adds extra energy into the Northern Hemisphere, increasing the difference in energy between the North and South and leading to changes in atmospheric circulation. In this project we were able to show that nearby to where trees are added responds in proportion to the area of trees that are changed, but when a large area of trees are added the climate response changes.  What happens is that with enough trees, the surface runs out of water at which point the response of climate switches from one regime to another.  However, while the large scale circulation of the atmosphere cares about the addition of tree cover, it doesn’t show this threshold response because it is just sensitive to the difference in energy between North and South and that is set by the darkness of the surface. This even holds during past climates, where we show that trees in Europe may have helped it rain over Africa.

 

Plants have been observed to change to adapt to future climate conditions by doing things like changing leaf thickness, and we know from our other work in the project that the atmosphere in some cases will be sensitive to changes in what plants look like and how they function. We were able to show that that a shift from larger and thinner leaves to smaller and thicker leaves alters the total area of leaves, and thus how leaves control the transfer of water from the soil to the atmosphere. This leads to warmer temperatures nearby to the plants that have changed, and is a significant size effect compared to other changes in plants over the past century.  However, even though there are observations of plants responding to future climate conditions in many instances, the size of response is not well known for different plant types and we don’t yet know why plants do this. Thus, our findings suggests an urgent need to make more observations for how and why we expect plants to change. 

 

Research from this project shows that the water savings that plants experience under high CO2 conditions compensate for much of the effect of warmer temperatures in the future, keeping the amount of water on land, on average, higher than we would predict with common drought metrics, and with a different spatial pattern. The implications of plants needing less water under high CO2 reaches beyond drought prediction to the assessment of climate change impacts on agriculture, water resources, wildfire risk, and vegetation dynamics.

 

This project advanced our broader impact goals by training graduate students to think and work across traditional disciplinary boundaries, as well as supporting scientists who come from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in these fields of study. We communicated with our scientific colleagues by presenting at scientific conferences, academic seminars, and workshops. Both graduate students on the project were given many opportunities to present their work to a variety of audiences, and participated in both group and peer mentoring. Our group worked with middle school girls as part of the “Girls In Science” program at the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture which reaches about 30 girls annually.  As part of the program we led middle-school aged girls through a series of three experiments demonstrating how plants interact with climate.
